facts.text: These appeals relate to Excess Profits Tax liability of the appellants in respect of two chargeable accounting periods April 1, 1944 to March 31, 1945 and April 1, 1945 to March 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-These appeals relate to Excess Profits Tax liability of the appellants in respect of two chargeable accounting periods April 1. 1944, to March 31., 1945, and April 1, 1945, to March 31, 1946.

facts.text: The appellants were under an agreement dated July 11, 1945 appointed managing agents for 20 years of the Coimbatore Spinning and Weaving Co, Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were under an agreement dated July 11, 1945, appointed managing agents for 20 years of the Coimbatore Spinning and Weaving Co, Ltd.-hereinafter referred to as the companypany.

facts.text: Prior to October 1, 1944, the appellants were the Managing Agents of the Coimbatore Mills Agency Ltd who were the Managing Agents of the company.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to October 1, 1944, the appellants were the Managing Agents of the Coimbatore Mills Agency Ltd--hereinafter referred to as the Agency Company who were the Managing Agents of the companypany.

facts.text: The year of account of the appellants ended on March 31, of the company on June 30, and of the Agency Company on September 30.

anchor.surface_text: The year of account of the appellants ended on March 31, of the companypany on June 30, and of the Agency Company on September 30.

facts.text: Under the agreement by which the appellants were appointed managing agents, remuneration provided: Office allowance at Rs. 1,500 per mensem, Commission at 1% on all purchases of cotton and stores and 2.5% on all capital expenditure, Commission at 10% on the net profits of the company due yearly after accounts closed.

anchor.surface_text: Under the agreement by which the appellants were appointed managing agents, the following remuneration was provided Office allowance at Rs. 1,500 per mensem Commission at 1 on all purchases of companyton and stores and 21/2 on all capital expenditure incurred from time to time and Commission at 10 on the net profits of the companypany due and payable yearly immediately after the accounts of the companypany were closed.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1945-46, the appellants submitted a return including Remuneration from Agency Company Rs. 36,000, Commission 10% from Agency to 30-9-1944 Rs. 37,953, Remuneration from company 1-10-1944 to 31-3-1945 Rs. 9,000, Commission 1% on cotton and stores Rs. 21,704.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1945-46, the appellants submitted a return of their income inclusive of the following items Remuneration from the Agency Company Rs. 36,000. Commission at 10 on profits from the Agency Company upto 30-9-1944 Rs. 37,953. Remuneration from companypany from 1-10-1944 to 31-3-1945 Rs. 9,000. Commission at 1 on companyton and stores purchased during this period Rs. 21,704.

facts.text: The 1945-46 return was accepted by the Additional Income-tax Officer, Coimbatore, and appellants assessed to income-tax; Excess Profits Tax worked out on same basis for period ending March 31, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: This return was accepted by the Additional Income-tax Officer, Coimbatore I II Circles, and the appellants were assessed to income-tax. Excess Profits Tax was also worked out on the same basis for the chargeable accounting period ending March 31, 1945.

facts.text: For assessment year 1946-47, appellants submitted return including Remuneration from company 1-4-1945 Rs. 18,000, Commission 10% on profits paid Dec 1945 for 1-10-1944 to 30-6-1945 Rs. 1,90,889, Commission 1% purchases 1-4-1945 to 30-6-1945 Rs. 16,777, Commission 2.5% capital exp 1-10-1944 to 30-6-1945 Rs. 1,690.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1946-47, the appellants submitted a return of their income which included the following items Remuneration from the companypany for one year from 1-4-1945 Rs. 18,000. Commission at 10 on the profits of the companypany paid in December 1945  1-10-1944 to 30-6-1945  Rs. 1,90,889. Commission at 1 on purchases of companyton and stores from 1-4-1945 to 30-6-1945 Rs. 16,777. Commission at 2 12/ on capital expenditure from 1-10-1944 to 30-6-1945 Rs. 1,690.

facts.text: Tax Officer directed commission on purchases and capital expenditure be taken for year April 1, 1945 to March 31, 1946; Rs. 1,127 from item 4 taken to previous year after reopening under s. 34 Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Tax Officer in charge of the assessment directed that the companymission on purchases and capital expenditure be taken into account for the year April 1, 1945, to March 31, 1946, and that the receipts-be companyputed accordingly. The amount of Rs. 1,127 attributable out of item 4 was accordingly taken into the account of the previous year after reopening the assessment under s. 34 of the Income-tax Act,

facts.text: Commission on profits apportioned between October 1, 1944 to March 31, 1945 and April 1, 1945 to June 30, 1945 by r. 9 Sch. 1 Excess Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: and the companymission on the profits of the companypany was apportioned between the period October 1, 1944, to March 31, 1945, and April 1, 1945, to June 30, 1945, by the application of r. 9 of Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

facts.text: Original assessment income tax Rs. 1,04,654, Excess Profits Tax Rs. 45,292; Revised: Income-tax loss Rs. 36,182, Excess Profits Tax Rs. 1,41,962-11-0 for 1945-46 and period to March 31, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: the liability of the appel- lants, original and revised, for income tax and Excess Profits Tax for the assessment year 1945-46 and chargeable accounting period April 1, 1944, to March 31, 1945, stood as follows Original assessment of income taxRs. 1,04,654. Excess Profits TaxRs. 45,292. Revised figures Income-tax  loss  Rs. 36,182. Excess Profits TaxRs. 1,41,962-11-0.

facts.text: For 1946-47 and period April 1, 1945 to March 31, 1946, tax liability Income-tax Rs. 1,66,271, Excess Profits Tax Rs. 1,13,163-5-0.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1946-47 and chargeable accounting period April 1, 1945, to March 31, 1946, tax liability was companyputed at Income-tax Rs. 1,66,271. Excess Profits Tax Rs. 1,13,163-5-0.

facts.text: Orders of assessment confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The orders of assessmentfor income tax and Excess Profits Tax were companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal referred four questions to Madras High Court on applications under s.66(1) IT Act and s.21 EPT Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the applications of the appellants for reference under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act and s. 21 of the Excess Profits Tax Act, the Tribunal drew up a statement of the case and submitted the following four questions to the High Court of Judicature at Madras

facts.text: High Court answered all questions against appellants in favour of Department.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered all the questions against the appellants and in favour of the Department.

facts.text: Appeals to Supreme Court with certificate under s.66A(2) Income-tax Act read with s.21 Excess Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the High Court, these appeals have been preferred with certificate granted under s. 66A 2  of the Income-Tax Act read with s. 21 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

facts.text: Appellants maintained books on cash basis; commission received from company credited after company accounts closed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants maintained their books of account on cash basis and companymission received from the companypany was credited after the accounts of the companypany were closed.

facts.text: Tax Officer committed error by not apportioning initially for Excess Profits Tax as chargeable periods did not tally with company accounting year.

anchor.surface_text: the Tax Officer companymitted an error. He overlooked the fact that the chargeable accounting period for the as assessment of Excess Profits Tax and the year of account of the companypany did number tally.

arguments.court_reasoning: Performance of managing agency contract extended across accounting periods; rule applies generally to contracts operative over fixed period beyond accounting period regardless of payment timing

arguments.claim: Contracts contemplated by r.9 are engineering/works contracts involving daily profit operations, not managing agency where remuneration payable after period for whole services

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants contends that the contracts contemplated by r. 9 are those of the nature of engineering or works contracts and the like where execution of the contract involves a profit making operation de die in diem and not contracts where remuneration is payable at a certain time for services performed throughout the stipulated period.

arguments.court_reasoning: Remuneration paid yearly but performance extended throughout year; managing agents perform duties whole year; annual contract cutting across periods

arguments.claim: r.9 Sch.1 applies to managing agency commission as performance extends beyond accounting period requiring proportional attribution

anchor.surface_text: The performance of the contract of managing agency extended beyond the period of account of the company which was July 1, 1945, to June 30, 1946 it covered parts of two accounting periods. The Tax Officer was therefore obliged to apportion to the, chargeable accounting periods the entire profits resulting from the complete performance of the contract in proportions properly attributable to the accounting periods and this, he proceeded to do.

arguments.claim: E.D. Sassoon case applies by analogy as managing agency commission accrues only on complete performance of annual period

arguments.court_reasoning: General rule for contracts spanning periods; applies to managing agency as annual performance

arguments.claim: r.9 terms general and applicable to all contracts operative for fixed period spanning accounting periods

anchor.surface_text: The terms in which r. 9 is enacted are general the rule is applicable to all contracts which are intended to be operative for a fixed period. If, for the performance of the entire contract, remuneration is payable at rates stipulated, the profit earned out of that remuneration must be apportioned in the manner provided by r. 9 if the performance of the contract extends beyond the accounting period

arguments.claim: Sassoon precedent distinguished as not involving r.9 apportionment

anchor.surface_text: But that was a case dealing with liability of the assessees who did not receive any income and to whom no income had accrued to pay income tax on the amounts of remuneration paid to their transferees. The court was not called upon to apply to income received by the assessee the principle of apportionment under r. 9 of Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act, or any provision similar thereto. It is r. 9 of Sch. I which attracts the principle of apportionment. The rule enunciated in Ms, E. D. Sassoon Co.s case 1 has therefore no application to this case,

holdings.text: it was open to the Tax Officer to take action under s. 15 of the Excess Profits Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that by the assessment of income made on the assumption that the chargeable accounting period and the accounting period of the companypany tallied, there resulted under assessment in the computation of tax liability for Excess Profits Tax, and it was open to the Tax Officer to take action under s. 15 of the Excess Profits Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Initial assessment overlooked mismatch between chargeable accounting periods and company's accounting year, leading to under-assessment based on definite information, allowing reassessment under s.15 EPT Act similar to pre-1948 s.34 IT Act

holdings.text: The Tax Officer was therefore obliged to apportion to the chargeable accounting periods the entire profits resulting from the complete performance of the contract in proportions properly attributable to the accounting periods

anchor.surface_text: The performance of the contract of managing agency extended beyond the period of account of the companypany which was July 1, 1945, to June 30, 1946 it covered parts of two accounting periods. The Tax Officer was therefore obliged to apportion to the, chargeable accounting periods the entire profits resulting from the complete performance of the contract in proportions properly attributable to the accounting periods and this, he proceeded to do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Managing agency contract performance extended across chargeable accounting periods despite yearly remuneration after accounts closure

holdings.text: the rule is applicable to all contracts which are intended to be operative for a fixed period. If, for the performance of the entire contract, remuneration is payable at rates stipulated, the profit earned out of that remuneration must be apportioned in the manner provided by r. 9 if the performance of the contract extends beyond the accounting period

anchor.surface_text: The terms in which r. 9 is enacted are general the rule is applicable to all contracts which are intended to be operative for a fixed period. If, for the performance of the entire contract, remuneration is payable at rates stipulated, the profit earned out of that remuneration must be apportioned in the manner provided by r. 9 if the performance of the contract extends beyond the accounting period

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.9 worded generally applies to any contract spanning accounting periods, including managing agency where duties performed throughout year even if commission computed annually on profits

holdings.text: the High Court was right in holding that the assessment made by the Excess Profits Tax Officer by apportionment of the commission income between the chargeable accounting periods was correct

anchor.surface_text: and the High Court was right in holding that the assessment made by the Excess Profits Tax Officer by apportionment of the commission income between the chargeable accounting periods was correct. The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Apportionment under r.9 proper for commissions on purchases, capital expenditure, and profits across periods, including specific amounts like Rs.1,127, Rs.1,43,163, Rs.37,129, Rs.2,299

anchor.surface_text: It is r. 9 of Sch. I which attracts the principle of apportionment. The rule enunciated in Ms, E. D. Sassoon Co.s case  1  has therefore no application to this case,

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.9 mandates apportionment regardless of Sassoon principle on accrual timing

precedents.citation: E. D. Sassoon Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay City 1

anchor.surface_text: E. D. Sassoon Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay City 1 on which strong reliance was placed by the appellants has numberapplication to this case. In that case, M s. E. D. Sassoon Co., Ltd. who were managing agents of three different companypanies transferred the managing agencies to three other companypanies on several dates during the accounting year. A question arose in the companyputation of income-tax payable by M s. E. D. Sassoon Co., Ltd. whether the managing agency companymission was liable to be apportioned between M s. E. D. Sassoon Co., Ltd. and their respective transferees in the proportion of the services rendered as managing agents for the respective periods of the accounting year.

precedents.case_name: E. D. Sassoon Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: managing agency contract is entire and indivisible; remuneration becomes due only on completion of the definite period of service; no remuneration payable for broken periods; no income accrued for partial performance
precedents.cited_holding: on a true interpretation of the managing agency agreements in each case, the contract of service between the companies and the managing agents was entire and indivisible and the remuneration or commission became due by the companies to the managing agents only on completion of definite periods of service and at stated intervals that complete performance was a condition precedent to the recovery of wages or salary in respect thereof and the remuneration payable constituted a debt only at the end of each period of service completely performed, no remuneration or commission being payable to the managing agents for broken periods

anchor.surface_text: pay  1 1955 1 S.C. R. 313. income tax on the amounts of remuneration paid to their transferees. The court was not called upon to apply to income received by the assessee the principle of apportionment under r. 9 of Sch. 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act, or any provision similar thereto. It is r. 9 of Sch. I which attracts the principle of apportionment.

precedents.case_name: E. D. Sassoon Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: managing agency contract is entire and indivisible; remuneration becomes due only on completion of the definite period of service; no remuneration payable for broken periods; no income accrued for partial performance

precedents.citation: M s, E. D. Sassoon Co.s case 1

anchor.surface_text: The rule enunciated in M s, E. D. Sassoon Co.s case  1  has therefore numberapplication to this case, and the High Court was right in holding that the assessment made by the Excess Profits Tax Officer by apportionment of the commission income between the chargeable accounting periods was correct. The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with costs.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 states Tax Officer 'obliged to apportion to the chargeable accounting periods the entire profits resulting from the complete performance of the contract', supporting Rule 9 on apportionment

anchor.surface_text: The performance of the contract of managing agency extended beyond the period of account of the companypany which was July 1, 1945, to June 30, 1946 it covered parts of two accounting periods. The Tax Officer was therefore obliged to apportion to the, chargeable accounting periods the entire profits resulting from the complete performance of the contract in proportions properly attributable to the accounting periods and this, he proceeded to do.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 states 'the rule is applicable to all contracts which are intended to be operative for a fixed period', supporting the application of Rule 9 Sch. 1

anchor.surface_text: The terms in which r. 9 is enacted are general the rule is applicable to all contracts which are intended to be operative for a fixed period. If, for the performance of the entire contract, remuneration is payable at rates stipulated, the profit earned out of that remuneration must be apportioned in the manner provided by r. 9 if the performance of the contract extends beyond the accounting period
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.
